title: Vinu Chakravarthy
text:
Vinu Chakravarthy (15 December 1945 – 27 April 2017) was an Indian actor, screenwriter and director who is known for acting in more than 1000 movies in <a href="Tamil%20language">Tamil</a>, <a href="Telugu%20language">Telugu</a>, <a href="Kannada">Kannada</a>, <a href="Badaga%20language">Badaga</a> and <a href="Malayalam">Malayalam</a> mostly as a comedian, supporting actor or in a villainous role. The 2007 released Tamil movie "<a href="Muni%20%28film%29">Muni</a>" was his landmark 1000th movie.
Early life and education.
Chakravarthy was born on 15 December 1945, in <a href="Usilampatti">Usilampatti</a> to Adimoola Thevar and Manjuvani Ammal. He studied at Wesley School, <a href="Royapettah">Royapettah</a> and graduated in <a href="commerce">commerce</a> from <a href="A.%20M.%20Jain%20College">A. M. Jain College</a>. He was eldest son among other 3 sons and a daughter.
Career.
On completion of his education, Chakravarthy worked as a Reserve <a href="Sub-Inspector">Sub-Inspector</a> at the Ice House <a href="police%20station">police station</a> for six months before joining the <a href="Southern%20Railway%20Zone%20%28India%29">Southern Railways</a> where he worked for four years.
Chakravarthy was working as a script writer for <a href="Kannada">Kannada</a> director <a href="Puttanna%20Kanagal">Puttanna Kanagal</a> when he was noticed by film producer Tiruppur Mani who, in 1977, gave him a role in the Kannada film "<a href="Parasangada%20Gendethimma">Parasangada Gendethimma</a>" which was later remade into Tamil as "<a href="Rosappu%20Ravikkaikari">Rosappu Ravikkaikari</a>" (1979) with Chakravarthy returning. Since then, Chakravarthy made over 1,000 films in four South Indian languages - 900 in Tamil, 30 in Malayalam, 5 in Telugu and one in Badaga language. He also directed movies on his own and is credited with introducing <a href="Silk%20Smitha">Silk Smitha</a>.
Controversies.
Chakravarthy criticised television and film producer <a href="Ekta%20Kapoor">Ekta Kapoor</a> for her depiction of <a href="Silk%20Smitha">Silk Smitha</a> in "<a href="The%20Dirty%20Picture">The Dirty Picture</a>", a biographical film on the actress. He also expressed displeasure over Kapoor's choice of casting. He also said Smitha had wide expressive, inviting eyes, which <a href="Vidya%20Balan">Vidya Balan</a> does not have.
